claim: To protect yourself against defamation claims in the U.S, only speak the truth.

supporting.text: Truth is an absolute defense against defamation claims in U.S. law, as established by legal precedent.

attacks.text: Truth is an absolute defense against defamation claims in U.S. law, as established by legal precedent.
Even if a statement is true, it can still be defamatory if made with actual malice or reckless disregard for the truth, as per New York Times Co. v. Sullivan.
New York Times Co. v. Sullivan primarily applies to public figures, and the 'actual malice' standard does not generally extend to private individuals in defamation cases.
Truth may not protect against defamation claims if the statement is presented in a misleading or selectively edited context that creates a false impression.
Courts typically evaluate the overall context of a statement, and isolated misleading edits may not suffice for defamation if the core factual assertion remains true.

supporting.text: Defamation requires a false statement of fact; truthful statements cannot meet this requirement.

attacks.text: Defamation requires a false statement of fact; truthful statements cannot meet this requirement.
Even truthful statements can lead to defamation claims if they are presented in a misleading or defamatory context.
Courts generally require the plaintiff to prove falsity, so truthful statements presented in a misleading way would still not meet the legal standard for defamation.
Some jurisdictions recognize 'half-truths' as defamatory if the omitted information changes the meaning of the statement.
The burden of proof remains on the plaintiff to show the statement was false or misleading, making 'half-truth' claims difficult to win.

supporting.text: The First Amendment protects truthful speech from defamation lawsuits under U.S. jurisprudence.

attacks.text: The First Amendment protects truthful speech from defamation lawsuits under U.S. jurisprudence.
Truthful speech can still be defamatory if it includes private facts not of public concern, violating privacy laws.
Privacy laws typically apply to disclosure of private facts, not defamation claims, which require false statements.
Even truthful statements can lead to defamation if made with actual malice in cases involving public figures.
Actual malice applies to false statements, not truthful ones, as established in New York Times Co. v. Sullivan.

supporting.text: Courts dismiss defamation claims when the defendant demonstrates the factual accuracy of their statements.

attacks.text: Courts dismiss defamation claims when the defendant demonstrates the factual accuracy of their statements.
Even true statements can be defamatory if made with malicious intent or reckless disregard for the truth.
Malicious intent is difficult to prove, and courts generally prioritize factual accuracy over subjective intent in defamation cases.
Some jurisdictions recognize 'truth' as an absolute defense, but others consider context, such as whether the statement serves a public interest.
The First Amendment strongly protects truthful speech, making context-based exceptions rare and narrowly applied.

supporting.text: Truthful statements, even if harmful to reputation, are not considered defamatory under U.S. legal standards.

attacks.text: Truthful statements, even if harmful to reputation, are not considered defamatory under U.S. legal standards.
Even truthful statements can be defamatory if they are disclosed with malicious intent or violate privacy laws.
Malicious intent is difficult to prove in court, and truth remains a strong defense against defamation claims.
Truthful statements can still lead to legal consequences if they involve the disclosure of confidential information.
Confidentiality agreements are separate from defamation law, and truth remains a defense in defamation cases.
